articles.headline: Shaken at First, Many Russians Now Rally Behind Putin’s Invasion
articles.snippet: Polls and interviews show many Russians now accept the Kremlin’s assertion that their country is under siege from the West. Opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
articles.abstract: Polls and interviews show many Russians now accept the Kremlin’s assertion that their country is under siege from the West. Opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stream of antiwar letters to a St. Petersburg lawmaker has dried up. Some Russians who had criticized the Kremlin have turned into cheerleaders for the war. Those who publicly oppose it have found the word “traitor” scrawled on their apartment door.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Valeriya Safronova

articles.headline: Amazon Workers on Staten Island Vote to Unionize in Landmark Win for Labor
articles.snippet: Despite heavy lobbying by the company, workers at the facility voted by a wide margin for a union. It was seen as a rebuke of the company’s treatment of its employees.
articles.abstract: Despite heavy lobbying by the company, workers at the facility voted by a wide margin for a union. It was seen as a rebuke of the company’s treatment of its employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a union organizing campaign that few expected to have a chance. A handful of employees at Amazon’s massive warehouse on Staten Island, operating without support from national labor organizations, took on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: What One ‘Brotherhood’ of Coal Miners Learned From a Year Above Ground
articles.snippet: The strike at an Alabama coal mine is one of the longest in U.S. history. To make ends meet, some striking miners have picked up work at an Amazon warehouse. It’s the same warehouse where workers are trying to unionize.
articles.abstract: The strike at an Alabama coal mine is one of the longest in U.S. history. To make ends meet, some striking miners have picked up work at an Amazon warehouse. It’s the same warehouse where workers are trying to unionize.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROOKWOOD, Ala. — Braxton Wright is a second-generation coal miner, a die-hard union supporter and, until recently, a staunch Republican. He is named after his uncle, a Korean War veteran, who was fatally crushed between two rail cars while working at the Pullman train factory near Birmingham.

articles.headline: Helping Hollywood Avoid Claims of Bias Is Now a Growing Business
articles.snippet: Studios are signing up consultants to help make sure their movies or shows don’t raise any cultural red flags.
articles.abstract: Studios are signing up consultants to help make sure their movies or shows don’t raise any cultural red flags.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, not long after the murder of George Floyd spurred a racial reckoning in America, Carri Twigg’s phone kept ringing.

articles.headline: One Weekend in Vegas With the Nation’s Auto Dealers
articles.snippet: After bottoming out early in the pandemic, profits and spirits are soaring — and people were ready to party.
articles.abstract: After bottoming out early in the pandemic, profits and spirits are soaring — and people were ready to party.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the National Automobile Dealers Association was able to hold its annual convention in person, the mood was far different. In a word, grimmer.

articles.headline: With Ukraine Invasion, Hungary’s Leader Softens His Embrace of Russia
articles.snippet: Facing an election on Sunday, Viktor Orban plays neutral peacemaker while campaigning against the “gender insanity” that he says is creeping in from the West.
articles.abstract: Facing an election on Sunday, Viktor Orban plays neutral peacemaker while campaigning against the “gender insanity” that he says is creeping in from the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEBRECEN, Hungary — The towering memorial, erected on the battlefield where the Russian imperial army routed Hungarian troops, mourns Russia’s 1849 victory over “brave homeland defenders.” It is a reminder of how, for centuries, the Hungarian psyche has been shaped and scarred by the specter of Russian domination.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: Russia in Broad Retreat From Kyiv, Seeking to Regroup From Battering
articles.snippet: A short drive from Kyiv in any direction turned up scenes of incinerated Russian vehicles, charred engine parts and chunks of armor. Attention is now shifting to the east, where Moscow says it is redirecting its forces.
articles.abstract: A short drive from Kyiv in any direction turned up scenes of incinerated Russian vehicles, charred engine parts and chunks of armor. Attention is now shifting to the east, where Moscow says it is redirecting its forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — The Russian forces that were intent on overwhelming Kyiv at the war’s start with tanks and artillery retreated under fire across a broad front on Saturday, leaving behind them dead soldiers and burned vehicles, according to witnesses, Ukrainian officials, satellite images and military analysts.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Garland Faces Growing Pressure as Jan. 6 Investigation Widens
articles.snippet: The inquiry is a test for President Biden and Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, who both came into office promising to restore the Justice Department’s independence.
articles.abstract: The inquiry is a test for President Biden and Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, who both came into office promising to restore the Justice Department’s independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Immediately after Merrick B. Garland was sworn in as attorney general in March of last year, he summoned top Justice Department officials and the F.B.I. director to his office. He wanted a detailed briefing on the case that will, in all likelihood, come to define his legacy: the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Katie Rogers and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Putin Reminds the World He Still Wields a Powerful Economic Weapon
articles.snippet: The Russian leader has stabilized the ruble and kept Europe’s leaders guessing by threatening to cut off energy. But he has left the country financially isolated.
articles.abstract: The Russian leader has stabilized the ruble and kept Europe’s leaders guessing by threatening to cut off energy. But he has left the country financially isolated.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the five weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine, the United States, the European Union and their allies began an economic counteroffensive that has cut off Russia’s access to hundreds of billions of dollars of its own money and halted a large chunk of its international commerce. More than 1,000 companies, organizations and individuals, including members of President Vladimir V. Putin’s inner circle, have been sanctioned and relegated to a financial limbo.

articles.headline: How Two Best Friends Beat Amazon
articles.snippet: The company’s crackdown on a worker protest in New York backfired and led to a historic labor victory.
articles.abstract: The company’s crackdown on a worker protest in New York backfired and led to a historic labor victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the first dark days of the pandemic, as an Amazon worker named Christian Smalls planned a small, panicked walkout over safety conditions at the retailer’s only fulfillment center in New York City, the company quietly mobilized.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Karen Weise

articles.headline: The Latest Covid Misinformation Star Says He Invented the Vaccines
articles.snippet: Dr. Robert Malone says he helped invent mRNA vaccines and has been wronged for decades. Now he’s spreading unfounded claims about the vaccines and the virus.
articles.abstract: Dr. Robert Malone says he helped invent mRNA vaccines and has been wronged for decades. Now he’s spreading unfounded claims about the vaccines and the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Va. — “I haven’t been able to ride a horse in months,” Dr. Robert Malone said from his 50-acre horse farm about two hours southwest of Washington. “It’s just a constant barrage of requests for assistance.”

articles.headline: ‘This Is True Barbarity’: Life and Death Under Russian Occupation
articles.snippet: The town of Trostyanets was occupied by Russian forces for a month before the Ukrainian military liberated it. Residents described weeks of hunger and horror.
articles.abstract: The town of Trostyanets was occupied by Russian forces for a month before the Ukrainian military liberated it. Residents described weeks of hunger and horror.
articles.lead_paragraph: TROSTYANETS, Ukraine — The last three Russian soldiers in this Ukrainian town are in the morgue, their uniforms bloodied and torn. The first one’s face is frozen in pain. The second has his wooden pipe in his lap. The third is stuffed in his sleeping bag.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Flurry of New Laws Move Blue and Red States Further Apart
articles.snippet: A wave of legislation, particularly in the West, is making states “not only a little different but radically different,” says one expert on government.
articles.abstract: A wave of legislation, particularly in the West, is making states “not only a little different but radically different,” says one expert on government.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — After the governor of Texas ordered state agencies to investigate parents for child abuse if they provide certain medical treatments to their transgender children, California lawmakers proposed a law making the state a refuge for transgender youths and their families.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan

articles.headline: In a Kyiv Suburb,‘They Shot Everyone They Saw’
articles.snippet: With Russian forces retreating, Ukrainians in Bucha are finding scores of bodies in yards and on the roads amid mounting evidence of intentional and indiscriminate killings of civilians.
articles.abstract: With Russian forces retreating, Ukrainians in Bucha are finding scores of bodies in yards and on the roads amid mounting evidence of intentional and indiscriminate killings of civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — When a column of Russian tanks drove into the Kyiv suburb of Bucha in the first days of the war, Tetiana Pomazanko thought they held Ukrainian soldiers and went out to her front gate to see.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: French Election Opens Up as Marine Le Pen Surges
articles.snippet: President Emmanuel Macron’s belated entry into the campaign and his focus on Ukraine have left him vulnerable to a strong challenge from the right.
articles.abstract: President Emmanuel Macron’s belated entry into the campaign and his focus on Ukraine have left him vulnerable to a strong challenge from the right.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — At last, Emmanuel Macron stepped forth. The French president entered a vast arena this weekend, plunged into darkness and lit only by spotlights and glow sticks, before a crowd of 30,000 supporters in a domed stadium in the Paris suburbs.

articles.headline: How the Recoil From Russian Gas Is Scrambling World Markets
articles.snippet: Europe wants 50 billion cubic meters of additional natural gas, but supplies are tight. Prices will rise, and other regions might have to do with less.
articles.abstract: Europe wants 50 billion cubic meters of additional natural gas, but supplies are tight. Prices will rise, and other regions might have to do with less.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just months ago, Germany’s plans to build a terminal for receiving shiploads of liquefied natural gas were in disarray. Would-be developers were not convinced customers would make enough use of a facility that can cost billions of dollars. And concerns about climate change undermined the future of a fossil fuel like natural gas.

articles.headline: Bristling Against the West, China Rallies Domestic Sympathy for Russia
articles.snippet: China’s Communist Party is mounting an ideological campaign aimed at officials and students. The message: The country will not turn its back on Russia.
articles.abstract: China’s Communist Party is mounting an ideological campaign aimed at officials and students. The message: The country will not turn its back on Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Russian troops have battered Ukraine, officials in China have been meeting behind closed doors to study a Communist Party-produced documentary that extols President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a hero.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Rigid Culture Bends to Demands for Flexibility at Work
articles.snippet: Many big banks are offering flexible working arrangements — sometimes grudgingly — as they chase talent that would rather stay home.
articles.abstract: Many big banks are offering flexible working arrangements — sometimes grudgingly — as they chase talent that would rather stay home.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tom Naratil arrived on Wall Street in the 1980s, work-life balance didn’t really exist. For most bankers of his generation, working long hours while missing out on family time wasn’t just necessary to get ahead, it was necessary to not be left behind.

articles.headline: Elon Musk becomes Twitter’s largest shareholder.
articles.snippet: The Tesla chief executive, who has been critical of Twitter’s content moderation policies, has bought 9.2 percent of the social media company.
articles.abstract: The Tesla chief executive, who has been critical of Twitter’s content moderation policies, has bought 9.2 percent of the social media company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Lauren Hirsch
